body.head: A TNAH TEI Customization
body.p:
This TEI ODD defines a TEI customization for factoids project in the context of the study of the french nobility in Ile-de-France region. It includes the five elements from the header module:
teiHeader from the header module to store required metadata
fileDesc from the header module to record information about this file
titleStmt from the header module to record information about the title
publicationStmt from the header module to detail how it is published
sourceDesc from the header module to record where it is from
Finally it also includes most of the elements from the "textstructure" module, but with a modification to exclude the numbered divs 1-7, as we rather want to use simple divs with type. We also exclude back and front as we want our main encoding to be stored in the body.

In addition to reorganizing tree-structured information into a graph data structure, the transition from TEI to linked data necessitates assigning a formal semantics to the entities by reusing existing ontologies whenever possible. As of today, there is no TEI-specific ontology, so all elements and attributes must be mapped to classes and properties from arbitrary ontologies (see [Eide 2014] and [Ciotti and Tomasi 2016]). There are two major challenges to performing such mapping. First, the chosen ontologies assign a formal semantics to the data, influencing how information is accessed and reused in the future. Users should be aware of the implications of using ready-to-use conversion tools like LIFT: the information conveyed by the original encoding may change when moving from one vocabulary, e.g. the TEI, to another, e.g. FRBRoo, CIDOC CRM, PROV-O, etc. Second, a knowledge graph is composed of entities (i.e. concepts), and links between entities (i.e. relationships between concepts). The distinction between what will become a concept and what will become a relationship is not inconsequential.
LIFTâ€™s collection of transformation scripts include: 1. Persons only 2. Persons and events 3. Persons and relations 4. Places only 5. Persons, events, relations, and places 6. Critical apparatus

The series of relation elements nested within listRelation markup relationships between persons in the TEI header. Note that listRelation must be a child element of listPerson, wuth attributes @active and @passive to express the subject and the object of the relationship respectively; for bidirectional relationships and the attribute @mutual.

As proposed by the LIFT project, we will begin to use the AgRelOn relationship ontology. To do this, we will constrain the name attribute to the relationships indicated in this ontology and organize the relationships into major types of relationships. These categories include kinship relations, affiliation relations with secular or religious institutions, economic relations (such as donation, transfer of goods, purchase, and sale), feudal relations, legal or judicial relations, and other types of relationships. Then an attribute category will be created for the leement relation. This approach will allow for a structured classification of relationships within the AgRelOn ontology framework, providing a comprehensive and organized system for categorizing various types of interpersonal and institutional connections. By implementing this structure, we can ensure a more consistent and standardized representation of relationships across different historical and cultural contexts, facilitating better analysis and interoperability of relational data within the LIFT project.

We will then define at least 3 rules 1) to be sure that the values of this ontology is used with two closed lists for the attribute @name and the attribute @category with the use of (attDef), 2) that the sourceDesc lists only in this order a msDesc, a listPerson, a listOrg, a listPlace, a listRelation, but no other lists as listEvent 3)to be sure that both @category and @name are used (content and sch:rule)

schemaSpec.desc: A minimal customisation for the students of TNAH at ENC.

elementSpec.desc: contains info about the sequence of list elements in sourceDesc : must contain a sequence of four elements: msDesc, listPerson, listPLace and listRelation as children. No other elements are allowed as list Event.

We will proceed with two significant modifications to enhance the structure and consistency of our data. First, we will establish a closed list of values for the name attribute of the element relation, which will limit the possible entries to a predefined set of relationship types, ensuring uniformity across all instances. Second, we will create a new attribute called category, which will also contain a closed list of categories, allowing us to group relationships into broader classifications. These changes will significantly improve the standardization of the relation element usage. By constraining the possible values for both the attributes name and category attributes, we will achieve greater consistency in data entry and representation. This structured approach will facilitate more efficient data analysis, improve interoperability between different parts of the project, and enable more accurate categorization of relationships.
